48:I[75400,["/_next/static/chunks/780ed9f12bd597e3.js","/_next/static/chunks/93fb432403aebbdd.js","/_next/static/chunks/6ed45c29e6db9297.js","/_next/static/chunks/ca6e69eece0158a1.js","/_next/static/chunks/c6ed05d45582b587.js","/_next/static/chunks/9674158a637507d8.js"],"StarIcon"]
2:Tfc7,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"FAQPage","mainEntity":[{"@type":"Question","name":"Is there really a quarantine for pets entering Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"No. Argentina does not require quarantine for cats and dogs entering from most countries, including the US, Canada, UK, and EU nations. As long as your paperwork is complete and valid, your pet clears customs at the airport the same day you arrive—usually within 30-60 minutes."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Are any dog breeds restricted or banned in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Argentina has no federal breed ban for imported dogs. However, some provinces and municipalities have local regulations around breeds like Pit Bulls, Rottweilers, and Dogo Argentinos that may require muzzling in public or proof of liability insurance. Buenos Aires city has no breed ban. Always check the local rules for your specific destination within Argentina."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"How much does it cost in total to bring a pet to Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"The DIY route typically costs $300-800 USD total, including vet health certificate ($50-150), USDA endorsement ($50-150), SENASA permit ($50-100), and airline pet fee ($100-500 depending on cabin vs. cargo). If you use a professional pet shipping company, expect $1,000-2,500+ including all paperwork, transport, and customs handling."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Does my pet need insurance in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Pet insurance is not required for entry, but it's highly recommended. Vet care in Argentina is affordable compared to the US, but emergencies can still be expensive. Companies like FetchPet (international plans) work in Argentina, and local options exist once you arrive. A basic plan covering emergencies runs about $15-30 USD/month."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Does my pet need a microchip to enter Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Argentina does not legally require a microchip for pet entry. However, having an ISO 15-digit microchip (ISO 11784/11785 standard) is strongly recommended. Many airlines require it, and it's essential for identification if your pet gets lost. If you plan to eventually return to the US or travel to the EU, a microchip will be required, so it's best to do it before leaving."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I bring multiple pets to Argentina at the same time?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Yes. There is no limit on the number of pets you can import for personal use. However, each pet needs its own complete set of documentation (health certificate, SENASA permit, rabies vaccination proof). Airlines typically allow 1-2 pets per passenger in the cabin—for more, you'll need to use cargo or book additional passenger seats on some carriers."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Can I bring exotic pets (birds, reptiles, ferrets) to Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Rules for exotic pets are significantly stricter than for cats and dogs. Birds face very strict import controls and may require CITES permits and lengthy quarantine. Reptiles and amphibians require special permits from Argentina's environmental authority (MAyDS) in addition to SENASA. Ferrets are treated similarly to cats/dogs but with additional health testing. Contact SENASA directly for specific requirements—regulations change frequently."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"Are there different rules for bringing pets from specific countries?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"The core requirements (health certificate, rabies vaccination, SENASA permit) apply universally. However, pets from countries where rabies is endemic may face additional blood titer testing requirements. Pets from the US, Canada, EU, UK, Australia, and Japan follow the standard process. Pets from countries in Africa, Asia, and parts of South America may need a rabies antibody titer test done at least 3 months before travel."}}]}0:{"buildId":"XJ7f5RvYDcX4yjbAXmNYG","rsc":["$","$1","c",{"children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex flex-col min-h-screen","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"BreadcrumbList\",\"itemListElement\":[{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":1,\"name\":\"Home\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\"},{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":2,\"name\":\"Pet Importation\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com/pet-importation\"}]}"}}],["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$2"}}],"$L3","$L4","$L5","$L6","$L7","$L8","$L9","$La","$Lb","$Lc","$Ld","$Le","$Lf"]}],["$L10"],"$L11"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}

Always confirm with your airline."}]]}]]}],["$","div","2",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex-col rounded-xl border shadow-sm flex gap-4 p-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex-shrink-0 w-10 h-10 rounded-full bg-primary text-primary-foreground flex items-center justify-center font-bold","children":2}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Get Rabies Vaccination (if not current)"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground text-sm","children":"Must be given at least 30 days before travel but within 1 year. If this is your pet's first rabies vaccine, the 30-day waiting period applies. Booster vaccines don't require the waiting period."}]]}]]}],["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex-col rounded-xl border shadow-sm flex gap-4 p-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex-shrink-0 w-10 h-10 rounded-full bg-primary text-primary-foreground flex items-center justify-center font-bold","children":3}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Apply for SENASA Import Permit"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground text-sm","children":"Your veterinarian or a pet shipping company can help with this. SENASA is Argentina's agricultural authority. The permit typically takes 1-2 weeks to process."}]]}]]}],["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex-col rounded-xl border shadow-sm flex gap-4 p-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex-shrink-0 w-10 h-10 rounded-full bg-primary text-primary-foreground flex items-center justify-center font-bold","children":4}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Veterinary Health Certificate (10 days before)"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground text-sm","children":"Visit your vet within 10 days of departure. They'll examine your pet and complete the international health certificate. Then get it endorsed by your country's official veterinary authority."}]]}]]}],["$","div","5",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex-col rounded-xl border shadow-sm flex gap-4 p-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex-shrink-0 w-10 h-10 rounded-full bg-primary text-primary-foreground flex items-center justify-center font-bold","children":5}],["$","div",null,{"children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Travel Day"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground text-sm","children":"Arrive at the airport early. Check in your pet, ensure they have water (some airlines require attaching a bowl to the crate). Keep copies of all paperwork with you and attached to the crate."}]]}]]}],"$L1a"]}]]}]}]}]
8:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-8 text-center","children":"Airline Travel Tips"}],["$","div",null,{"className":"grid md:grid-cols-2 gap-6","children":[["$","div","Book Direct Flights",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Book Direct Flights"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground text-sm","children":"Minimize stress and reduce chances of delays or lost paperwork. Connections in third countries complicate things."}]}]]}],["$","div","Check Airline Pet Policies",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Check Airline Pet Policies"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground text-sm","children":"Each airline has different size/weight restrictions for cabin vs. cargo. Larger pets go in climate-controlled cargo hold."}]}]]}],["$","div","Carrier Requirements",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Carrier Requirements"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground text-sm","children":"Must be airline-approved, ventilated, and allow pet to stand, turn, and lie down comfortably. Get your pet used to it weeks before."}]}]]}]]}]]}]}]}]

e:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold text-center mb-8","children":"Frequently Asked Questions"}],["$","$L37",null,{"type":"single","collapsible":true,"className":"w-full","children":[["$","$L38","0",{"value":"faq-0","children":[["$","$L39",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Is there really a quarantine for pets entering Argentina?"}],["$","$L3a",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"No. Argentina does not require quarantine for cats and dogs entering from most countries, including the US, Canada, UK, and EU nations. As long as your paperwork is complete and valid, your pet clears customs at the airport the same day you arrive—usually within 30-60 minutes."}]]}],["$","$L38","1",{"value":"faq-1","children":[["$","$L39",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Are any dog breeds restricted or banned in Argentina?"}],["$","$L3a",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Argentina has no federal breed ban for imported dogs. However, some provinces and municipalities have local regulations around breeds like Pit Bulls, Rottweilers, and Dogo Argentinos that may require muzzling in public or proof of liability insurance. Buenos Aires city has no breed ban. Always check the local rules for your specific destination within Argentina."}]]}],["$","$L38","2",{"value":"faq-2","children":[["$","$L39",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"How much does it cost in total to bring a pet to Argentina?"}],["$","$L3a",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"The DIY route typically costs $300-800 USD total, including vet health certificate ($50-150), USDA endorsement ($50-150), SENASA permit ($50-100), and airline pet fee ($100-500 depending on cabin vs. cargo). If you use a professional pet shipping company, expect $1,000-2,500+ including all paperwork, transport, and customs handling."}]]}],["$","$L38","3",{"value":"faq-3","children":[["$","$L39",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Does my pet need insurance in Argentina?"}],["$","$L3a",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Pet insurance is not required for entry, but it's highly recommended. Vet care in Argentina is affordable compared to the US, but emergencies can still be expensive. Companies like FetchPet (international plans) work in Argentina, and local options exist once you arrive. A basic plan covering emergencies runs about $15-30 USD/month."}]]}],["$","$L38","4",{"value":"faq-4","children":[["$","$L39",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Does my pet need a microchip to enter Argentina?"}],["$","$L3a",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Argentina does not legally require a microchip for pet entry. However, having an ISO 15-digit microchip (ISO 11784/11785 standard) is strongly recommended. Many airlines require it, and it's essential for identification if your pet gets lost. If you plan to eventually return to the US or travel to the EU, a microchip will be required, so it's best to do it before leaving."}]]}],["$","$L38","5",{"value":"faq-5","children":[["$","$L39",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Can I bring multiple pets to Argentina at the same time?"}],["$","$L3a",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Yes. There is no limit on the number of pets you can import for personal use. However, each pet needs its own complete set of documentation (health certificate, SENASA permit, rabies vaccination proof). Airlines typically allow 1-2 pets per passenger in the cabin—for more, you'll need to use cargo or book additional passenger seats on some carriers."}]]}],["$","$L38","6",{"value":"faq-6","children":["$L3b","$L3c"]}],"$L3d"]}]]}]}]}]

This is the most common restriction. Larger dogs significantly narrow your options in apartment buildings."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Breed restrictions:"}]," Rare but some luxury buildings prohibit \"dangerous breeds\" (Pit Bull, Rottweiler, Dogo Argentino). Newer buildings are generally more lenient."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Number of pets:"}]," Most buildings that allow pets accept 1-2. Three or more can be difficult. Houses (casas) in neighborhoods like Saavedra, Devoto, and outer barrios are more flexible on quantity."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Building rules (reglamento):"}]," Each consortium (building association) sets its own rules. Some require pets to be carried through common areas or use the service elevator. Ask for the reglamento before signing."]}]]}]]}]]}]
30:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Deposits and Extra Costs"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 space-y-3","children":["$","ul",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground space-y-2","children":[["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Pet deposit:"}]," Not standard practice in Argentina. Most landlords don't charge an additional pet deposit beyond the normal rental deposit (typically 1-2 months rent)."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Standard deposit:"}]," Under current Argentine rental law, the deposit is capped at 1 month's rent for contracts of 3+ years. Temporary rentals (often used by expats) may charge 1-2 months."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Expensas (building fees):"}]," Monthly building maintenance fees ($30-150/month) don't typically increase for pet owners, but some buildings charge a small premium."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Negotiation tip:"}]," If a landlord is hesitant about your pet, offering a slightly higher deposit or sharing photos/references of your well-behaved pet can help. Many landlords care more about the tenant than the pet—being a responsible expat with income goes a long way."]}]]}]}]]}]
33:["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":"Argentina's long-distance bus system is extensive but historically not pet-friendly. This is changing slowly:"}]
34:["$","ul",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground space-y-2","children":[["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Most bus companies do not allow pets"}]," except service animals. This includes major companies like Andesmar, Via Bariloche, and Chevallier."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Small pets in carriers:"}]," Some drivers may allow a very small pet in a carrier on their lap, but this is unofficial and not guaranteed. Don't count on it for trip planning."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Alternatives:"}]," For long-distance travel with pets, driving (rent a car) is the most reliable option. Some pet transport companies offer door-to-door service for long hauls."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Rent a car:"}]," Car rental in Argentina runs $25-60 USD/day. Companies like Hertz, Avis, and local chains allow pets (confirm when booking). This is the best option for destinations like Bariloche, Mendoza, or Mar del Plata with a pet."]}]]}]

36:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg flex items-center gap-2","children":[["$","$L22",null,{"size":"md","className":"text-amber-500"}],"Climate and Regional Considerations"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 space-y-3","children":["$","ul",null,{"className":"text-sm text-muted-foreground space-y-2","children":[["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Buenos Aires summers (Dec-Feb):"}]," Hot and humid, 30-38°C (86-100°F). Walk dogs early morning and after 7 PM. Carry water. Sidewalks can burn paws midday. Heat stroke is a real risk for brachycephalic breeds."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Patagonia (year-round):"}]," Strong winds and cold temperatures. Ensure your dog has appropriate cold-weather gear if visiting in winter (June-August). Altitude in mountain areas can affect some dogs—acclimate gradually."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Northern Argentina (Salta, Jujuy, Misiones):"}]," Subtropical heat. Higher risk of leishmaniasis (transmitted by sandflies)—ask your Argentine vet about preventive treatments before traveling north. Tick-borne diseases are also more common."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Altitude:"}]," Destinations like Purmamarca (2,200m), Tilcara (2,461m), and mountain passes can affect dogs just like humans. Symptoms include lethargy, loss of appetite, and panting. Gradually increase altitude and ensure plenty of water."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Poisonous toads:"}]," The Argentine toad (Rhinella arenarum) is common in suburban gardens and parks, especially in humid areas. Their skin secretions are toxic to dogs. If your dog mouths one, rinse the mouth immediately with water and see a vet."]}]]}]}]]}]
3b:["$","$L39",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Can I bring exotic pets (birds, reptiles, ferrets) to Argentina?"}]
3c:["$","$L3a",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Rules for exotic pets are significantly stricter than for cats and dogs. Birds face very strict import controls and may require CITES permits and lengthy quarantine. Reptiles and amphibians require special permits from Argentina's environmental authority (MAyDS) in addition to SENASA. Ferrets are treated similarly to cats/dogs but with additional health testing. Contact SENASA directly for specific requirements—regulations change frequently."}]
3d:["$","$L38","7",{"value":"faq-7","children":[["$","$L39",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"Are there different rules for bringing pets from specific countries?"}],["$","$L3a",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"The core requirements (health certificate, rabies vaccination, SENASA permit) apply universally. However, pets from countries where rabies is endemic may face additional blood titer testing requirements. Pets from the US, Canada, EU, UK, Australia, and Japan follow the standard process. Pets from countries in Africa, Asia, and parts of South America may need a rabies antibody titer test done at least 3 months before travel."}]]}]
41:null
